title: The Capture of Samson

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on panel.

description: This panel, made as a sketch for a larger painting com- missioned by the mayor of Antwerp, Nicolas Rockox, demonstrates the influence of the ancient and modern art Peter Paul Rubens studied in Italy. The subject comes from a story in the Hebrew Bible in which the mighty Samson awakes to find that his lover, Delilah, has cut off his hair, the source of his strength. Rubens drew from ancient Roman sculpture for Samson’s contorted pose as he is captured by soldiers, while the strong contrast of light and dark recalls the work of 16th-century Italian painter Tintoretto—for example, Tarquin and Lucretia.

New York, Wildenstein, A Loan Exhibition of Rubens, February 20 –March 31, 1951, no.  3.

Cologne, Wallraf-Richartz-Museum,  September 4 – November 22, 1992,  Von Bruegel bis Rubens.  Das goldene Jahrhundert der flämische Malerei, cat. 44.4; Antwerp, Koninklijk Museum voor Schone Kunsten, December 12, 1992 – March 8, 1993; Vienna, Kunsthistorisches Museum, April 2– June 20, 1993.

Cincinnati, Cincinnati Art Museum, Drawn by the Brush: Oil Sketches by Peter Paul Rubens, 11 June 2005 – 11 September 2005, no. 3.

London, National Gallery, Rubens:  A Master in the Making, 26 October 2005 – 15 January 2006, no.  73.

Antwerp, Rockexhuis, Samson and Delilah: A Ruben Painting Returns, November 16, 2007–February 10, 2008, cat. 4;Vienna, Liechtenstein Museum, February 29 – May 25, 2008.

Madrid, Museo Nacional del Prado, Rubens: Painter of Sketches, April 9– August 5, 2018, cat. 6; Rotterdam, Museum Boijmans Van Beunigen, September 9, 2018 – January 13, 2019.

San Francisco, Legion of Honor Museum, Early Rubens, April 6 - September 8, 2019, no cat. no.; Ontario, Art Gallery of Ontario, October 12, 2019 - January 5, 2020.
provenance_text: Probably in the collection of the artist, Antwerp, until his death in 1640 and then included in a large lot of oil sketches in his estate sale, 1642 [Jeffrey M. Muller, “Oil-Sketches in Rubens’s Collection,” Burlington Magazine 117 (1975), pp.  374-75, and Held 1980, p. 11, argue that the oil sketches were disposed of in this way].  Frank T. Sabin Gallery, London, by 1914 [Arundel Club 1914, no. 14]; sold through W.R. Valentiner to the Art Institute, November 1923 [as by Van Dyck, according to a letter of August 1, 1923 from Valentiner to Robert Harshe in Art Institute archives and receipt from Sabin dated November 5, 1923, copies in curatorial file].
